1.    The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source

At the Erie County Sewer District No. 6 (ECSD #6) Lackawanna Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP), personnel are continually concerned with the safety of employees, the public, and the environment.  The Accidental Release Prevention Program mandates operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process at this facility.  To prevent possible releases of regulated substances, appropriate controls and techniques are used.  If such a release does occur, personnel at the Lackawanna WWTP, through the Division of Sewerage Management (DSM) are coordinated with the Erie County Department of Emergency Services and the Lackawanna Fire Department, whom all commit highly trained emergency response crews to help control and ease the effects of the release.


2.    The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled (primary activities, use of regulated substances, & quantities handled or stored)

?    The Lackawanna WWTP?s primary activity involves the treatment of wastewater.  Presently, there is one (1) regulated toxic substance above threshold quantity at this facility, which is Chlorine (Cl2).  According to the regulations, the Lackawanna WWTP is required to comply with the Program 3 Prevention Program.

?    Chlorine is used for the disinfection of wastewater, primarily to destroy and/or deactivate pathogenic organisms.

?    The maximum inventory of Chlorine at this facility is 12,000 lbs., which is broken down into six (6) one-ton (2,000 lb.) cylinders.  There are two (2) cylinders on each of the two (2) scales, and the remaining two (2) cylinders on the floor, with only one (1) cylinder in use at any given time.


3.    The Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario (include scenario & distance to endpoint).

The ALOHA (Areal Locatio

ns of Hazardous Atmospheres) modeling program, version 5.2.3, was used to attain the required offsite consequence analysis for this facility.  The following provides a summary of the Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios:

The WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO submitted for Program 3 toxic substances involves a disastrous release from one of the chlorine cylinders.  In this particular scenario, 2,000 lbs. (the entire mass of the cylinder) of Chlorine is released in a gaseous form, over a ten (10) minute span.  Under worst case weather conditions being Class F atmospheric stability, 25?C (77?F), 50% humidity, no cloud cover, and 1.5 m/s (3.35 mph) windspeed, the maximum threat zone distance for a level of concentration (LOC) of 0.0087 mg/L is 2.7 miles.
 
The ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO for Chlorine involves a release from a single chlorine cylinder and is assumed to be a failure at the transfer hose, due to over pressurization or human error.  In this scenario, 800 lbs. of Chlorine will be released in a gaseous form over a six (6) minute span.  The contents that remain in the tank after the pressurized gas is released will be of liquid chlorine.  This liquid would be at a level lower than the release point and therefore, the contents would remain in the tank.  Under neutral weather conditions (taken from Local Climatological Data 1999-2001 for Buffalo, NY) being Class C stability, 49?F (9.4?C), 45% humidity, 5/10 cloud cover, and 9.8 mph (4.38 m/s) windspeed, the maximum threat zone distance for a level of concentration (LOC) of 0.0087 mg/L is 1.7 miles.


4.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

At the ECSD #6 Lackawanna WWTP, personnel have taken all the steps needed to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements found in 40 CFR, Part 68.  This facility is subject to the OSHA PSM and EPCRA section 302 standards.  A brief description of the elements in the Release Prevention Program are as follows

:

Safety Information
The Lackawanna WWTP keeps a written record of safety information that includes information on the chemical hazards, operating procedures, and all equipment used within the process. 

Process Hazard Analysis
In May 1997, the Lackawanna WWTP conducted a thorough analysis to ensure that hazards associated with the process were identified and responded to efficiently.  The methodology used to determine and evaluate the hazards of the process was the What If/Checklist.  The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is reviewed and updated (if necessary) and revalidated every five (5) years.  Any changes resulting from the PHA are completed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
To safely conduct activities involved within the process, the Lackawanna WWTP personnel maintain written operating procedures.  These procedures address each operating phase including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after an emergency shutdown.  Each year, the Chief WWTP Operator reviews the operating procedures and certifies in the annual report that all current operating practices are reflected.  In addition, all operating procedures are readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the process.

Training
The Lackawanna WWTP has an extensive training program in place to ensure that employees involved with the process are completely knowledgeable about the operating procedures and hazards associated with them.  Mandated refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years and more often if necessary, to each employee involved in operating the process.  Currently, training is ongoing throughout the year in many areas.
 
Mechanical Integrity
At the Lackawanna WWTP, personnel carry out routine maintenance checks, inspections, and testing on all process equipment to ensure proper functioning.  Process equipment that is accounted for, but is not limited to, includes pressure

vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Any equipment deficiencies that are outside acceptable limits are corrected in a safe and timely manner to assure safe operation.

Management of Change
Written procedures are established at the Lackawanna WWTP to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Any employee whose job tasks are affected by a change in the process are informed and trained.

Pre-startup Reviews 
Pre-startup safety reviews related to modifications in the established process are conducted as needed.  These reviews confirm that construction, equipment, safety, operations, and maintenance procedures are in place and adequate prior to startup.

Compliance Audits
The Lackawanna WWTP evaluates compliance at least every three (3) years.  Any corrective actions required as a result of the audit are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
During the past five (5) years, there have not been any incidents at the Lackawanna WWTP.  If and when the occasion arises, any incident that has resulted in or could reasonably result in a disastrous release of a regulated substance would promptly be investigated.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  

Employee Participation
The Lackawanna WWTP has incorporated any appropriate employee comments into the Process Safety Management Plan (PSMP) (Appendix A).  In addition, all employees have access to the information developed under this standard. 

Contractors
If the situation arises that an outside contractor must be hired to perform any maintenance and/or construction work, before choosing a contractor, the Lackawanna WWTP will evaluate information regarding the contractors safety performance and programs. The contractors will be informed of the known potential h

azards related to the work and the process.  In addition, contractors will be explained any applicable provisions of the Emergency Response Plan (ERP) (Appendix C).


5.    The Five-Year Accident History
The Lackawanna WWTP has an outstanding record of preventing accidental releases.  Due to effective release prevention, no accidental releases have occurred over the last five (5) years.

 
6.  The Emergency Response Program
The Lackawanna WWTP has a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP) (Appendix C) that deals with accidental releases.  The procedure includes aspects of emergency response including monitoring and detection, notifications following a release, direction and control, containment, evacuations, mutual aid assistance, emergency equipment inventory, first aid, review, updates and training, and other emergencies.  The emergency response equipment is inspected, tested, and maintained in accordance with the DSM Respirator Program and the computer maintenance management system.  The ERP is reviewed annually and promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the process.

The Facility Emergency Coordinators (FEC) for the Lackawanna WWTP are: 
?    Sewer District Manager, Lawrence Krug
?    Chief WWTP Operator, James Kaszubowski
?    Senior WWTP Operator, Gregory Michalak
?    Chief WWTP Supervisor, Glenn H. Absolom Jr. 
The ERP (Appendix C) has been coordinated and verified with each FEC.  This procedure is also coordinated with the Erie County Department of Emergency Services and the Lackawanna Fire Department.


7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Lackawanna WWTP has all safety aspects covered, and have no planned changes at this time.
